Terms and Definitions in Postmortem Path.name: Terms and Definitions in Postmortem Pathology

Definitions.text: Death certificate (DC): Legal document recording fact of death, signed by physician who certifies manner and immediate and underlying cause of death and factors contributing to death
States are responsible for registration of death and have their own DC; most follow outline proposed by federal government
Physicians are responsible for medical portion of DC

Manner of Death.text: How death occurred: Natural or external (non-natural) causes (e.g., natural, homicide, accident, suicide, pending further investigation, and could not be determined)
Physicians and non-forensic pathologists limited to certifying natural deaths; if manner questionable, consult medical examiner or coroner
Medical examiner will either accept case and certify death Â± autopsy or release case
If medical examiner releases case but autopsy pathologist questions manner, refer again to medical examiner or coroner
If injury (however remote) started chain of events leading to death, manner is external (nonnatural) (e.g., pneumonia in patient made paraplegic from homicide attempt months prior)

Amending Death Certificate to Revise Cau.text: If autopsy findings significantly change cause of death as listed on DC, certifying physician must report revised cause of death to appropriate state agency (usually vital records or local registrar)

Minimum Requirements.text: Autopsy final reports must contain either direct statement as to immediate and underlying cause of death or enough information so that primary clinician can determine immediate and underlying cause of death

If autopsy findings as to immediate and underlying cause of death are significantly different from what is listed on death certificate, this needs to be reported to certifying physician so that death certificate can be amendedThis situation also likely indicates clinically unsuspected diagnosis, which alerts pathologist to report this according to institutional quality assurance procedureAutopsy pathologist should be aware of how death was certified if certification was performed prior to autopsy or without use of available autopsy dataEven with modern imaging and diagnostic techniques, major discrepancies are still noted between certified causes of death and cause of death determined by autopsy

Clinical Correlates.text: Correct, defensible certification of manner of death is critical to families, epidemiological data collection, and legal system
Natural death must be completely natural in manner; all other categories considered unnatural (except potentially undetermined); all contributing factors must be considered
In every case, consider proximate cause of death and chain of events leading to immediate cause of death
Homicide and suicide in particular require careful consideration and strong circumstantial support
Controversy exists among forensic pathologists about manner of death, especially in complex cases; any well-considered opinion is legitimate

Positive identification uses DNA, fingerprints, and dental comparison
Less than positive identification requires as many consistencies as possible, without discrepancies that cannot be explained
Autopsy is important opportunity for obtaining potentially identifying information
Identification often involves other forensic specialists (e.g., odontologist, anthropologist, forensic biologist [for DNA])

Terminology.text: Pneumothorax is defined as presence of air in pleural space

Tension pneumothorax is progressive accumulation of entrapped air within pleural space that results in pressure-induced displacement of mediastinum and heart, resulting in potentially fatal hemodynamic compromise

Etiology/Pathogenesis.text: Extensive number of underlying lung diseases, as well as traumatic and iatrogenic injury

Clinical Issues.text: Differences in presentation and outcome based on whether patient is spontaneously breathing or on mechanical ventilation, with the latter being more difficult to recognize and more likely to result in mortality

Macroscopic Features.text: Tracheal deviation, mediastinal shift, and pneumomediastinum
Unilateral lung collapse with positive test for air in pleural space
Signs of prior intervention

Microscopic Features.text: Findings consistent with specific underlying lung disease predisposing to pneumothorax or recent lung injury

Definitions.text: Primary (spontaneous) pneumothorax: Pneumothorax in patients with no known underlying lung disease
Secondary pneumothorax: Pneumothorax associated with known underlying lung disease, trauma, or iatrogenic injury
Pleural bleb: Airspace within pleura and separated from pleural space and alveoli by thin pleural membrane that may rupture and lead to pneumothorax
Bullae: Airspaces that are characteristically subpleural and associated with destruction of lung tissue
Pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, pneumoperitoneum, and subcutaneous emphysema: Air in mediastinum, pericardial space, peritoneal cavity, or subcutaneous tissue

Pathogenesis.text: Injury to lung or pleura â communication between airspace and pleural space with so-called valve effect
When valve is created, air accumulates in pleural cavity during respiratory cycleValve is 1-way only, allowing for entry of air during inspiration but not for its escape during expiration
sub_points: Valve is 1-way only, allowing for entry of air during inspiration but not for its escape during expiration

Pathogenesis.text: Accumulation of air â intrapleural pressure and interferes with lung expansion on pneumothorax side
â intrapleural pressure â effect of ipsilateral lung collapse and pushes mediastinal structures and heart toward opposite side
Compression of vena cava and right heart compromises venous return, diastolic filling, and cardiac output
Significant shunting with ventilation-perfusion mismatch leads to hypoxemia, acidosis, and shock
Decompression of pleural space must be prompt to avoid fatal hemodynamic compromise
If air escapes into interstitial tissue planes, pneumomediastinum, pneumopericardium, pneumoperitoneum, and subcutaneous emphysema may result

Presentation.text: Symptoms: Ipsilateral pleuritic chest pain, progressive tachycardia, respiratory distress, diaphoresis, hypotension and pallor from hypoxemia, mediastinal shift, and reduced venous return

Treatment.text: Early recognition and prompt intervention before hemodynamic deterioration is essential
Hemodynamic improvement is achieved through release of entrapped air, usually by tube thoracostomy
Following decompression, patients are at risk for reexpansion pulmonary edema (REPE) that may further complicate recovery

Prognosis.text: If untreated, fatal cardiovascular collapse can occur even in healthy, young individuals
As would be expected, mortality is increased in patients with more severe comorbidities who are less able to tolerate hemodynamic compromise and particularly in ventilated patients in ICU setting

Radiographic Findings.text: Tracheal deviation toward opposite side from pneumothorax, flattening of diaphragmatic contour, displaced cardiac silhouette, shifting of left cardiac border

Benefits of Accurate Death Certification.text: For decedent, it legally documents that person's death and permits burial/cremation to proceed
For family, it assists in settlement of estates, insurance policies, and survivor benefits
For public, it facilitates compilation and evaluation of mortality data, informs epidemiology, influences allocation of research and health programs, and optimizes public health interventions
For society, it allows adjudication of criminal and civil matters, latter including personal injury, healthcare liability, and insurance and workman's compensation claims

Medical examiners can also provide incorrect causes of death when autopsy is not performed (i.e., only external examination performed)
Interactive workshops are likely most effective means of improving DC competency among health care providers

General Considerations.text: Health care providers in hospital setting can only certify deaths that are exclusively due to natural disease(s)
Hospital pathologists in theory should only perform autopsies in patients with natural disease(s)

If in course of preparing for or conducting hospital autopsy, pathologist becomes aware that nonnatural pathology may have caused &/or contributed to death, then process should be stopped at that point and local medical examiner/coroner (ME/C) should be consulted for guidance on next stepsME/C may accept jurisdiction of deathME/C may take custody of body, or it may allow hospital autopsy to proceed and then use those findings to certify deathIf hospital autopsy proceeds, consider omitting COD statement from autopsy report, or at least ensure it matches official DCME/C may not accept jurisdiction of death, in which case hospital autopsy can proceed in usual fashionAutopsy report should document (usually in clinical summary section) that ME/C was contacted about and declined jurisdiction over deathProcedures, accidents, and drugs (PAD) represent commonly overlooked underlying COD

Good Practices.text: Autopsy final reports should either directly state underlying COD (with immediate &/or intermediate COD as needed) or provide sufficient pathologic information so that decedent's health care provider can discern and then provide on DC accurate COD

Autopsy pathologists should know clinical COD before commencing autopsy (preferably through talking with health care provider requesting autopsy or by checking DC)If autopsy findings significantly change COD listed on DC, pathologist should encourage decedent's health care provider to amend COD and DCThis situation also likely indicates presence of clinically unsuspected diagnosis, which in turn should prompt pathologist to report autopsy findings in accordance with institutional quality assurance proceduresEven with modern imaging and diagnostic techniques, major discrepancies are still noted between COD certified by health care provider and COD determined at autopsy

Good Practices.text: Although health care providers should know medical histories of decedents on whom they request autopsies, it ultimately remains autopsy pathologist's responsibility to ensure that potential nonnatural causes of death (almost always underlying COD) and therefore nonnatural manners of death are identified and appropriately triaged with local ME/C for sake of public healthWhen evaluating and composing COD statements, keep asking "due to what" until etiologically specific underlying COD is identified, and then ask "what were circumstances under which this underlying COD occurred" to ensure any nonnatural manner of death is identified

Produce detailed provisional autopsy reports to assist clinicians in completing accurate DCs in timely fashion
Include COD statement in all final autopsy reports
Incorporate COD statements in all presentations (e.g., medical student classes, department autopsy conferences, hospital clinicopathologic conferences) to teach by example
Teach learners and physicians about DC (interactive workshops likely are most effective method for such education)
Become DC resource for local and regional health care providers
